flowRoot.flowPara: The hot plasma is kept from touching the walls of the machine by the use of strong magnetic fields 100,000 times stronger than the earth's magnetic field at the surface. The magnetic fields are generated by sets of coils surrounding the tokamak. To learn more about these magnets and their interaction with plasma PRESS "M".

Scientists use a variety of methods to heat the plasma. While the main way is through the induced current (see Central Solenoid), auxiliary sources of power are needed to reach the conditions for fusion. Shown is a heating antenna launching radio waves into the tokamak. To learn more about auxiliary sources PRESS "M".

The central solenoid is an electromagnet that creates a current inside the plasma. This current is responsible for, both, heating the plasma as well a providing an essential component of the magnetic field required to confine the plasma. In this simluation, the current increases proportional to the magnetic field. PRESS "M" to learn more.

The tokamak itself is a stainless steel donut-shaped shell that is kept at ultra high vacuum. Deuterium and tritium gas is injected into the vessel and heated until it is ionized and becomes plasma (PRESS "P" to learn about plasmas). The density of the plasma can be changed by varying the amount of fuel injected into the machine (among other methods). For more info about the vacuum vessel and density control PRESS "M".

Press this button to enter the tokamak reactor cell. The tokamak is the most studied magnetically confined plasma device in the world. The final objective of this research is to use the tokamak to create electricity via fusion energy. In the Virtual Tokamak simulator, you are the operator of an energy producing tokamak reactor. You must maximize the electric power produced while being careful not to damage the machine by making the plasma unstable. This simulation uses an energy equilibrium model based on real plasma physics.
To learn more about plasma, fusion and tokamaks, PRESS "M".
To remotely turn on and study a real plasma, visit the Remote Glow Discharge Experiment by PRESSING "R".

Press this button to enter the heat and tritium exchanger system. Once the conditions for sustained fusion within the tokamak are obtained, the reactions generate energetic helum nuclei and neutrons (at energies millions of times higher than those of fossil fuel reactions). This energy ultimately heats the blanket and wall of the tokamak. The heat and tritium exchanger convert this heat to usable electricity as well as extract the tritium atoms produced in the blanket and inject them back into the tokamak to be used as fuel.
To learn more about the exchangers PRESS "M".

Press this button to view the city being powered by fusion. This is the final step in fusion energy production: Getting the electricity produced via fusion to the people that need it, be it to power cities, industries, electric vehicles, etc.

The Virtual Tokamak can produce more than 1GW of electricity, enough to power a city the size of Seattle, WA (check this), while consuming only about 500 pounds of fuel a year (50% deuterium, 50% tririum). How much electricity can you make it produce?
To learn more about the potential energy production of fusion and its efficiency PRESS "M"

The vacuum vessel is surrounded by a thick shell mostly made out of lithium. This is the blanket. The fusion reactions in the reactor create energetic neutrons that are ejected towards the blanket heating it through collisions. The neutrons also react with the lithium in the blanket, producing tritium. The heat and tritium are extracted from the blanket via cooling channels. To learn more PRESS "M"

The blanket is cooled by liquid lithium lead (LiPb) which, once it's flown through the blanket, is heated and carries the tritium produced. Upon leaving the blanket, the lithium passes through a tritium extraction system which removes the tritium from the LiPb and channels it back towards the tokamak as fuel. To learn more PRESS "M"

Once the heat has been transfered to the helium in the heat exchanger, the helium is run through a heat engine which turns turbines. These, in turn serve as power generators, producing electricity. For more details PRESS "M".

Once the tritium is extracted from the hot liquid lithium lead (LiPb), the LiPb is fed to a heat exchanger which is connected to a helium loop. The heat is transfered from the LiPb to the helium. The cooled LiPb returns to the blanket while the heated helium heads to the electricity producing turbines. To learn more PRESS "M".

This slider controls the amount of deuterium and tritium (represented by blue and green particles respectively) in the tokamak. Since the atoms enter the machine neutral, that is, with one electron, the plasma has the same number of ionized atoms as it does electrons. The density is, therefore, also the electron density. If the density is too low, not enough fusion reactions can occur. If the density is too high, the plasma can lose its delicate equilibrium and disrupt. This can be damaging to the machine’s inner wall. Keep this in mind as you optimize the output power.

The first way of heating the plasma is through an externally induced current (press “c” for a full discussion of this process). This method, known as ohmic heating, is transient, although we’re artificially making it steady state in this system. Therefore other “auxiliary” means of powering the plasma are necessary. The 2 main ways are through neutral beams (press “n” for more info) and through radio frequency waves (press “w” for more info). Modifying the auxiliary power increases the stored energy but also uses external power so keep this in mind as you tune it. As fusion starts occurring, the main source of heating becomes the energetic helium nuclei created in the reactions. As this new source dominates, we get to the point where the plasma is self heating, that is, when it ignites.

The externally supplied magnetic field is necessary for confining the plasma. The plasma follows tight spirals around the magnetic field lines, hence you can trace a field line by following a given particle as it goes around the machine. Conventional electromagnets are limited by the amount of current they can carry and how hot they can get, but with conventional and high temperature superconducting coils (press “H” for more info on HT superconductors), energy producing fusion reactors are expected to run indefinitely with routine maintenance periods every year or so.

Even though the plasma is confined by the magnetic field, there is always heating of the walls due to radiation and stray plasma hitting it. For a routine fusion plasma, this heat will be extracted and used as part of the electricity creating cycle. Nevertheless, when the plasma equilibrium is broken and the plasma diprupts (press "D" for more info), the energy carried by the plasma current is dumped on the walls and in extreme cases it can damage them. In the VT, the wall health is the limiting factor of operation. In a real fusion energy plant, these disruption must be eliminated or controlled or else they will also be detrimental for the reactors.

As the plasma heats up due to the many sources of power: Induced heating, auxiliary power and the energetic helium nuclei; the random kinetic energy of the plasma increases. This is another way of saying that its temperature rises. The temperature reached by the plasma is of order 10,000 electron volts (eV). since 1eV = 11,600K (Kelvin), this is about 116 million K, or about 10 times the temperature of the center of the sun.

The heat from the blanket is extracted and used to heat helium in the final step of the heat exchanger. After this, the hot helium is used as the driver of a closed-cycle gas turbine which is similar to a steam engine and electricity is produced (press "T" for more info). From this, the electricity used to power the machine. In this simulation, we only subtract the auxiliary power and the ohmic power but in a real plant, some power goes into other sinks, like the cooling of superconducting and/or traditional electromagnets.

The score is a function of Q which is the ratio between the fusion power produced and the external input power (press “Q” for more info). Q=1 is the critical point at which the same amount of energy is going in as coming out (as heating of the blanket. This is called break even and is a score of 25. Anything beyond this and you’re creating more energy than what’s used. How high can you go?

There is an empirical density limit beyond which the plasmas lose confinement and disrupt (press “D” to read more). The limit goes up as more current is flowing in the plasma, and, in this simulation, this current is linked to the external magnetic field. Therefore, if you want to be able to reach higher densities, try raising the magnetic field.

Beta is the ratio between the plasma pressure (the product of density and temperature) and the energy carried by the magnetic field. If the pressure is too high, the plasma becomes susceptible to instabilities that lead to disruptions. In this simulation we impose the Troyon beta limit (press “T” for more info). To move away from the limit you can reduce the value of Beta, either reducing the density or increasing the magnetic field.
